channel.title: Comments on: Analyzing IB Physics Exam Language Programmatically
channel.description: iteration, making, building, and coding in education

item.title: By: Evan Weinberg
item.dc:creator: Evan Weinberg
item.description:
In reply to <a href="/2014/12/18/analyzing-ib-physics-exam-language-programmatically/#comment-351">Cleargrace</a>.
Wordle would have worked too, but it wouldn't have let me exclude as many words as I was able to exclude using my custom solution. Thank you for the suggestion.
I've never thought so carefully about vocabulary until lately when it is the primary stumbling block for students in IB physics. The mathematics doesn't even come to play until the students understand what is actually being discussed in a problem.

item.title: By: Evan Weinberg
item.dc:creator: Evan Weinberg
item.description:
In reply to <a href="/2014/12/18/analyzing-ib-physics-exam-language-programmatically/#comment-352">Chris Hamper</a>.
Hi Chris,
Those really look useful - I'll send my students there. The more I teach, I find that deliberate work on vocabulary is a necessity. This has become more true as I think about my own assumptions about using vocabulary. 'Speeding up' is a great example - a student new to English might assume this means moving upwards. It's important not to overlook the colloquial language as an obstacle for these students.
I'm a big fan of your work Chris - thanks for stopping by!

item.title: By: Chris Hamper
item.dc:creator: Chris Hamper
item.description: It's interesting how words are used in exam questions. I'm always unintentionally confusing my students with expressions like "speeding up" and "slowing down". I started making some quizlets ( http://quizlet.com/subject/chrishamper/ ) of words for each section of the syllabus. Not sure how useful they are but anyone is welcome to use them

item.title: By: Cleargrace
item.dc:creator: Cleargrace
item.description: Thank you for parsing the list - I would probably just have used wordle! I am a for believer in teaching the more formal and rich testing vocabulary to my kids. I think it is the reason students do so poorly on tests. We don't talk or teach in that formal structure, so it doesn't make sense for students without the level of vocabulary. I also believe it is critical to teach the terms in context - and in math, that usage is often very different than regular language usage. I think you are on the right track!
